text: So does trading based on signals alone not really work and I need to think smarter to take advantage of what the market might do based on them signals?

elements.text: So does trading based on signals alone not really work and I need to think smarter to take advantage of what the market might do based on them signals?

text: I'm not sure I'd go so far as saying it wouldn't work but I would say less experienced (automated) traders focus too much on coming up with their price and not enough on market behaviour

elements.text: I'm not sure I'd go so far as saying it wouldn't work but I would say less experienced (automated) traders focus too much on coming up with their price and not enough on market behaviour

text: If you're starting out I'd recommend you don't try to be too clever - find signals of value that other people don't know about and use them. Focus on how your bets match and try to drive your average return per transaction up - don't try to scale your volume. Years down the line you can start trying to pick off rivals for fun but you don't need to worry about that any time soon.

elements.text: If you're starting out I'd recommend you don't try to be too clever - find signals of value that other people don't know about and use them. Focus on how your bets match and try to drive your average return per transaction up - don't try to scale your volume. Years down the line you can start trying to pick off rivals for fun but you don't need to worry about that any time soon.

text: By how your bets match does that mean how long it takes them to match?

elements.text: By how your bets match does that mean how long it takes them to match?

text: Every aspect of matching. How long they take to match, what you match rate is, whether you benefit from best-ex. Everything.

elements.text: Every aspect of matching. How long they take to match, what you match rate is, whether you benefit from best-ex. Everything.

text: Matching analysis gets insanely complicated, far harder than value analysis in my experience. I've been doing this for a living for a decade and I haven't got optimal matching down.

elements.text: Matching analysis gets insanely complicated, far harder than value analysis in my experience. I've been doing this for a living for a decade and I haven't got optimal matching down.

text: To offer some contrast, my strategies work primarily by using models to generate prices based on in play activity, and just take if the the diff between market prices and mine is >=x% (without paying attention to market dynamics)

elements.text: To offer some contrast, my strategies work primarily by using models to generate prices based on in play activity, and just take if the the diff between market prices and mine is >=x% (without paying attention to market dynamics)

text: So you don't do much execution optmisation?

elements.text: So you don't do much execution optmisation?

text: Thats interesting Dave as thats the kind of thing i was trying (but probably with a lot less logic to the generated price), do you then let the trade play out or green up?

text: <@UUCD6P13J> - correct, my logic is as follows: take current state of the event (could be football match, race) -> encode to machine understandable values (aka features) -> get the model to forecast an outcome -> convert the forecast probability to a price -> take in the market if there is value. And no I never green up, greening up doesn't make sense in 99% of situations IMO.

elements.text: - correct, my logic is as follows: take current state of the event (could be football match, race) -> encode to machine understandable values (aka features) -> get the model to forecast an outcome -> convert the forecast probability to a price -> take in the market if there is value. And no I never green up, greening up doesn't make sense in 99% of situations IMO.

text: do you generally find there's a lot of wiggle room between your fair value and the market pricing?

elements.text: do you generally find there's a lot of wiggle room between your fair value and the market pricing?

text: That's exactly how I operate Dave, but with an added layer that's looking at market dynamics and anticipating the effect of my bets in the market. Without generating a price you can't determine what value your bets will have, but without some understanding of what's happening in the market and how your bets will be received you can't bet optimally. The more value you request (in the form of your price) and the larger your stake the lower your match rates will be so there's a yield curve that determines the optimal bet to post in any given situation. That situation is described by a whole lot of variables that interact in quite complex ways.  That's what makes it difficult and keeps me interested.

elements.text: That's exactly how I operate Dave, but with an added layer that's looking at market dynamics and anticipating the effect of my bets in the market. The more value you request (in the form of your price) and the larger your stake the lower your match rates will be so there's a yield curve that determines the optimal bet to post in any given situation. That situation is described by a whole lot of variables that interact in quite complex ways.  That's what makes it difficult and keeps me interested.

text: <@U01093Z1KF0> - if I were to quantify I'd say 50% of my bets only see value of around 10% of the forecast probability, i.e. market says an event is 60% likely and my models say 66%.

text: <@UGV299K6H> - indeed, you pretty much hit the nail on the head there. If you want to be putting through decent volume then you most definitely need to look at market impact. The only optimization I've made is to bet over a longer time period rather than go in with a large swipe.

elements.text: - indeed, you pretty much hit the nail on the head there. If you want to be putting through decent volume then you most definitely need to look at market impact. The only optimization I've made is to bet over a longer time period rather than go in with a large swipe.

text: <@UUCD6P13J> - it takes historical data into account, I spend a lot of time gathering clean, consistent data and transforming it and getting rid of anomalies and etc.

elements.text: - it takes historical data into account, I spend a lot of time gathering clean, consistent data and transforming it and getting rid of anomalies and etc.

text: My edge is very tiny btw, maybe 6% or so (my strike rate Vs implied strike rate from the odds I take at). And tiny volumes compared to other guys here.

elements.text: My edge is very tiny btw, maybe 6% or so (my strike rate Vs implied strike rate from the odds I take at). And tiny volumes compared to other guys here.

text: <@UUCD6P13J> In my case I don't use form or anything like that, but I do use the whole history of the market, so I'm not just analysing an instantaneous snap shot of the market but how things are changing over time. It can be done on a snapshot though so if you're starting out that's a reasonable way to proceed without too much complexity.

elements.text: In my case I don't use form or anything like that, but I do use the whole history of the market, so I'm not just analysing an instantaneous snap shot of the market but how things are changing over time. It can be done on a snapshot though so if you're starting out that's a reasonable way to proceed without too much complexity.

text: <@U0128E7BEHW> 6% seems like plenty to me if that's the edge on the bets you match.  My own edges are very variable depending on the situation and in general I post bets with quite small margins to maximise match rates.

elements.text: 6% seems like plenty to me if that's the edge on the bets you match.  My own edges are very variable depending on the situation and in general I post bets with quite small margins to maximise match rates.

text: <@UUCD6P13J> I won't lie, it takes a lot of effort to make a model that makes any reasonable predictions (reasonable being anything better than random). I suggest arming yourself with various statistical test that can give you confidence that your model actually makes sense (stuff like precision-recall, Area under the ROC curve, etc etc.). Good luck!

elements.text: I won't lie, it takes a lot of effort to make a model that makes any reasonable predictions (reasonable being anything better than random). I suggest arming yourself with various statistical test that can give you confidence that your model actually makes sense (stuff like precision-recall, Area under the ROC curve, etc etc.). Good luck!

text: <@U0128E7BEHW> Assuming you're making steady profits the main thing for someone at your stage would be to very careful about how you scale. It's tempting to imagine that you can just raise your stakes and you'll be rich but that won't happen. Focus on finding out very specifically where your profits are coming from then try to expand on that by seeing what lessons you can draw from your insights and how they might apply elsewhere. Build gradually and when you're developing your betting think about how you can generate data as well as making a profit. For example that might mean randomising your pricing in a range around what you think is an optimal price. That way you'll have something meaningful to analyse afterwards.

elements.text: Assuming you're making steady profits the main thing for someone at your stage would be to very careful about how you scale. It's tempting to imagine that you can just raise your stakes and you'll be rich but that won't happen. Focus on finding out very specifically where your profits are coming from then try to expand on that by seeing what lessons you can draw from your insights and how they might apply elsewhere. Build gradually and when you're developing your betting think about how you can generate data as well as making a profit. For example that might mean randomising your pricing in a range around what you think is an optimal price. That way you'll have something meaningful to analyse afterwards.

text: I agree that it's good but I think it depends what kind of markets you're operating in. For IR horses you do need the market to be showing quite a lot of value. It also depends how you're counting;  Whether it's what you're posting, what you're matching or something else - anyone can post bets with a lot of edge. Also the term 'edge' gets used quite loosely, some people use it when they're talking about value which confuses things.

text: Ah OK - I'd define edge as the difference between the frequency of an outcome and its implied probability per odds - IE backs matched at 2 have to win 56% of the time to have 6% edge. Then expected value is decimal price matched * probability of winning - 1 (if backing)

text: <@U4H19D1D2> What I mean is: You model a horse as having 10% chance of winning but you match it at 50. Under your definitions the 'edge' in your bet is 400% (which I would call your expected value) - so what's your name for the 8% that I would call 'edge'?

text: So you just skip the probabilities and only analyse the value of a transaction... I think we do things quite differently. In my methodology I want to know exactly where the whole market is at so that if somethings's being over backed I can see where the balancing over-laying is and whether I can get both. For that you need to be watching all the IPs and reckoning them up to 1, hence my focus on the probability discrepancies that I call 'edge.'

For that you need to be watching all the IPs and reckoning them up to 1, hence my focus on the probability discrepancies that I call 'edge.'
